webTitle: Mat Ryan stands tall but shootout euphoria fails to mask Socceroos' problems | Scott McIntyre

fields.headline: Mat Ryan stands tall but shootout euphoria fails to mask Socceroos' problems
fields.standfirst: Australia’s base was solid but they again had trouble breaking down well-organised opponents
fields.trailText: Australia’s base was solid but they again had trouble breaking down well-organised opponents
fields.byline: Scott McIntyre at Khalifa bin Zayed Stadium
fields.body:
At the end of a tight, scoreless, 120 minutes in Al Ain it took penalties to split Australia and Uzbekistan with Mathews Ryan and Leckie standing up when it most counted to send the Socceroos into the Asian Cup quarter-finals. Keeper Ryan made two superb saves and the returning Leckie coolly slotted home the decisive spot kick as Australia edged the Uzbeks 4-2 in the shootout to book their place in Saturday’s last-eight game against hosts UAE.

Related: Australia beat Uzbekistan on penalties to reach Asian Cup last eight

But the euphoria of the win might gloss over the fact that Australia had a mountain of trouble in breaking down tightly-packed opposition. Equally, though, the Uzbeks rarely threatened at the other end and remarkably Ryan made the same number of saves in the shootout (two) that he did in the preceding two hours of action.

Losing Tom Rogic to suspension for the next match won’t help with the UAE also expected to sit deep and look to frustrate the Socceroos, but with such a steady presence at the back Australia will always be a hard side to beat. Along with Iran’s Alireza Beiranvand, Ryan has been the best keeper in the tournament and it was the 26-year-old’s initial save that helped keep Australia level in the shootout after Aziz Behich had seen his effort, the team’s second, saved.

Having lightheartedly declared that he’s not a “mind reader” when asked if he had an idea of which way to dive during the shootout, Ryan did admit that his late heroics were a mixture of preparation and luck.

“There’s a lot of technology available in this day and age that you take advantage of and just before the game there are some clips we look at [of previous Uzbekistan penalties] and you see if you can pick up anything off it,” he said. “As a goalkeeper you need a bit of luck though with the decision you make in terms of if you go one side or stay up the middle and also luck in terms of the shooter making the same decision and then you can make the save and thankfully it happened twice today.”

His teammates were indebted to him and as the Brighton & Hove Albion player stood talking with the assembled press post-match, a collection of Socceroos delivered a series of what can be construed as compliments – including “king”, “tiger” and “champ” – on their way past.

So too Leckie, who made a telling contribution in his first action of the tournament after finally overcoming a hamstring injury. Introduced in the 68th minute, the forward immediately provided a sharper cutting edge to an Australian attack that had struggled to break down a well-organised Uzbek side. His performance will give coach Graham Arnold food for thought as he weighs up whether to throw him in from the start against the UAE.

The most telling contribution from the Hertha Berlin man, though, came at the most important juncture as he stepped up as Australia’s fifth penalty taker, knowing a successful effort would secure their spot in the final eight.

“A few of the boys that had taken penalties before me noticed that their keeper stood up and held his feet for a very long time,” Leckie said. “When I went up I thought if I hit it hard and in a corner even if he chooses the right way then he waits so long he won’t be able to save it and in the end I ended up hitting it really, really hard and it was the perfect penalty at the perfect time.”

Related: Australia beat Uzbekistan on penalties: Asian Cup last 16 – as it happened

It was also a vindication of the gamble that the Socceroos staff took in including a player in the final 23-man squad who they knew might not be able to feature at all in the tournament due to an injury suffered with his Bundesliga side.

“When I sat down with the medical staff at the start of the tournament they said there’s a small chance that something could go wrong along the way and I said I’m ready to take the risk because any chance to play at the Asian Cup I wanted to take,” the 27-year-old said. “Then Arnie had to take a decision as well whether he wanted to take the risk on a spot on a player who isn’t going to play in the group stage and in the end so far I guess it’s worked out well but there’s still a long way to go in the tournament.”

Three matches to be precise are what now stand between the Socceroos and a successful defence of their Asian Cup crown. Improvement is needed – Andrew Nabbout’s expected return to fitness should provide a further boost – but in a tournament where no nation has yet laid down a real marker, Australian hopes remain alive.

webTitle: A Year of British Murder review – a coldly mechanical collage of 768 tragic deaths

fields.headline: A Year of British Murder review – a coldly mechanical collage of 768 tragic deaths
fields.standfirst: A documentary examining every murder committed in 2017 takes awful tales of deep, abject grief and skims over every single one
fields.trailText: A documentary examining every murder committed in 2017 takes awful tales of deep, abject grief and skims over every single one
fields.body:
There is, of course, an unending, unyielding pathos to the stories told by the unendingly, unyieldingly bereaved people in a programme about death. All the more so when that bereavement has been occasioned by a means as brutal as murder.

This gathering of such awful tales, in A Year of British Murder, was no exception. The perfect evocation of the happy ordinariness of life, remembered by Shaun Woodburn’s best friend after Shaun was beaten to death outside a pub, broke your heart. “We didn’t do amazing things,” he said. “The best time was literally sitting in my mum’s house. Being together was the main thing.” The five-year-old asking a friend who stepped where her 17-year-old brother’s ashes had just been scattered: “Why you stepping on Kyle?” made you glad their mother had felt unable to attend the ceremony for her boy.

“I got a last kiss off my Lisa, my lovely girl,” said the mother of a woman killed by her boyfriend one ordinary night, as she smoothed the lipstick-blotted tissue she found when clearing out her daughter’s home. Subtitles ran beneath the Romanian mother of Razban Sirvu as she spoke about her murdered son – “I miss him very much. As my only child, he will always be part of me” – but she had the same fathomless grief in her eyes as Shaun and Kyle and Lisa’s parents, and hardly needed translating.

You have to serve such stories well, and A Year of British Murder faltered. You can see the superficial attraction of the conceit: to move through a year – 2017, in which there were 768 victims of murder or manslaughter – giving voice to the people behind the statistics, is an obvious way to structure such a piece. But in practice, it had unforeseen disadvantages.

There was something coldly mechanical about using people to illustrate the numbers. Here was The One Who Represents the 105 Victims of Terrorism There Have Been Since 2000; here was The One Who Represents the 38% of Victims Who Are Murdered With a Knife or Sharp Implement. Next up – One of the 17% For Whose Murder There Is No Known Motive.

The demands of chronology and mere representation meant that there was sometimes strikingly little time or weight given to certain stories. Notably so in the case of Tina Billingham, killed after years of abuse by her partner, Ron, leaving her two sons still clearly struggling with the cumulative weight of all that had gone on.

Aisha Harris got a few scant minutes to limn the life of her son Ruben, shaken to death aged six months by his father (“Children under one have the highest rate of homicide in Britain” ran the badly-worded caption, so we were clear which category we were ticking off now), or her own since. She did note how she tried to pretend it was just social services that had taken him away.

In the end, and because this approach meant that each story only covered the initial stages of each suffering family’s or friends’ grief, you had the impression of a murder collage rather than any cohesive picture of cause or effect beyond that which any marginally sentient person can be assumed to understand and appreciate already.

And so you have to ask – and I think you must ask, when you are asking vulnerable people to participate in such a programme and share their loss – what is the point? It wasn’t an exploration of grief or how its evolution is affected by the circumstances of the loved one’s death, and by swift and effective punishment (or not) of the killer. It wasn’t an investigation into murderers’ motives or mindsets.

It performed, at best, two functions. The lesser one was as confirmation of what we – surely to God, though he has as surely forsaken us long ago – already knew; that murder is appalling, the psychic wound depthless and the breach of natural and every other kind of justice all but unendurable. The greater one was as a testimony to the bravery of the people who do endure, who fight – such as Shaun’s father and others – for such scraps of justice as remain to be won and who simply manage to go on, somehow, in a state of unimaginable pain.

I don’t think it’s enough, but perhaps – especially if taken in the round with other shows on the subject that opt for other approaches and do drill down – I’m wrong. Maybe it brought some tiny measure of peace to all who took part, either way.

webTitle: MLK's son criticizes Pence for using father's memory to push for border wall – as it happened

fields.headline: MLK's son criticizes Pence for using father's memory to push for border wall – as it happened
fields.standfirst:
King’s oldest son rejects vice-president’s comparison of civil rights leader to Trump: ‘MLK was a bridge builder, not a wall builder’

  • Kamala Harris officially enters 2020 US presidential race
  • Democratic hopefuls head south – where black voters hold the key
  • Start your day with our US morning briefing. Sign up.
fields.trailText: King’s oldest son rejects vice-president’s comparison of civil rights leader to Trump: ‘MLK was a bridge builder, not a wall builder’
fields.body:
10.20pm GMT

Closing summary

We’re wrapping now. These are today’s key politics stories.

  • California Senator Kamala Harris announced her campaign for president.
  • Official and potential 2020 contenders delivered lofty speeches at events marking Martin Luther King Jr. Day.
  • Meanwhile, Donald Trump made a two-minute visit to the MLK monument in Washington, and the civil rights hero’s son criticized vice-president Mike Pence for invoking his dad in making the case for a border wall.
  • The TSA said that a record-high one in ten of its agents did not show up for work Sunday, as the government shutdown continued through its 30th day.

We’ll be back tomorrow with more live coverage. Until then, you can sign up to receive our US morning briefing for a summary of the day’s top stories and must-reads.

Updated at 10.42pm GMT

10.18pm GMT

The Guardian’s Hubert Adjei-Kontoh reports:

At a packed Harlem church this afternoon congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez sat down with the award-winning writer Ta-Nehisi Coates at an event marking Martin Luther King’s legacy.

Ocasio-Cortez rejected Donald Trump’s latest proposal to trade temporary protections for young immigrants for money for a border wall, saying there was no reason to give $5 billion to an “unstable person.” The new Congresswoman also touted her proposal to tax the richest Americans at a 70% marginal rate, an idea that was warmly received at the event at Riverside Church.

Asked if she was considering running for president (which would have to wait until 2024, since she’s too young to run in 2020), Ocasio-Cortez said she was not, arguing that the fixation on higher office “prevents people from speaking truth to power.”

10.05pm GMT

About those 8,000-plus false and misleading statements from Donald Trump during his presidency: It makes for grueling work for the fact checkers.

The Guardian’s Adam Gabbatt reports:

Since taking office, the president has lied about everything from immigration figures to the number of burgers he served to the Clemson football team at the White House last week.

“It takes up a lot of our time just because he is constantly talking,” said Glenn Kessler, editor and chief writer of the Washington Post’s Fact Checker column.

“The pace in Washington has changed. You could wake up and the president may have already had five or six tweets that cry out for fact checks.”

Kessler and the Washington Post responded by creating an ongoing database tracking Trump’s lies. But that comes with its own problems.

“It’s become an all-consuming task. In the month of October he said 1,200 things that were false or misleading. There’s some days where he’s topped more than 100 false or misleading claims.”

9.51pm GMT

The Washington Post has tallied Donald Trump’s untruths, and finds that the president made at least 8,158 false or misleading statements in the two years since he took office.

That includes 6,000 such statements in his second year alone, according to the paper’s Fact Checker. That adds up to nearly 5.9 false or misleading claims a day in year one, which went up to 16.5 a year in year two.

8.51pm GMT

King's son criticizes Pence

Martin Luther King III criticized the vice-president for invoking his father’s memory in making the push for a wall along the US-Mexico border.

“The hearts and minds of the American people today are thinking a lot about it being the weekend we remember the life and work of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.,” Pence said Sunday on CBS’s “Face the Nation.”

“One of my favorite quotes from Dr. King was ‘now is the time to make real the promises of democracy.’ You think of how he changed America,” he said. “He inspired us to change through the legislative process to become a more perfect union. That’s exactly what President Trump is calling on the Congress to do: Come to the table in a spirit of good faith. We’ll secure our border, we’ll reopen our government.”

King’s son rejected the comparison while speaking at a National Action Network MLK Day breakfast, CNN reported.

“Martin Luther King Jr. was a bridge builder, not a wall builder,” he said. “Martin Luther King Jr. would say love not hate would make America great. Did you all hear that? Love not hate would make America great.”

Updated at 9.16pm GMT

8.23pm GMT

Donald Trump did not speak to Michael Cohen before Cohen false testimony to Congress about a Trump Tower project in Moscow, Rudy Giuliani said Monday - the latest reversal from the president’s lawyer.

“The President never spoke with Cohen about the congressional testimony,” Giuliani told the New York Daily News.

On Sunday, Giuliani told CNN’s “State of the Union” that he wasn’t sure whether Trump talked to Cohen about his testimony. “So what if he talked to him about it?” he said.

8.03pm GMT

The Guardian’s Max Benwell reports:

In a conversation with writer Ta-Nehisi Coates at Harlem’s Riverside Church, Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez discussed her tendency to shoot down critics on social media.

“Whoever is coming at me in my mentions with a blue check when I haven’t eaten in three hours ... Until more people start pitching in and holding people to account, I’m just going to let them have it,” she said.

Updated at 8.04pm GMT

7.58pm GMT

White House press secretary Sarah Sanders has drawn some backlash for a tweet saying that Martin Luther King Jr “gave his life to right the wrong of racial inequality.”

7.47pm GMT

Writer Ta-Nehisi Coates is interviewing Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez at a Martin Luther King Jr. Day event at Manhattan’s Riverside Church.

7.32pm GMT

Rep. Hakeem Jeffries, speaking at the National Action Network MLK Day event, called Donald Trump the “grand wizard of 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue,” a reference to the Ku Klux Klan.

7.23pm GMT

Gizmodo finds some evidence that Donald Trump’s team has been posting altered photos to his Facebook and Instagram accounts to make him look thinner and his fingers longer.

7.20pm GMT

Senator Kamala Harris entered the crowded Democratic 2020 race for US president with a tribute to a woman who broke barriers in American politics decades earlier.

The Guardian’s Sam Levin reports:

The California senator’s logo is a nod to Shirley Chisholm, the first woman and African American to seek the nomination for president in a major political party, in 1972.

Harris, the former attorney general of California, has chosen a red and yellow design for her logo that resembles the campaign buttons used five decades ago by Chisholm, the first black woman elected to Congress.

Harris, the daughter of immigrants from India and Jamaica, has broken barriers throughout her meteoric rise in California politics. The Democrat was the first African American and first woman to be elected San Francisco district attorney in 2003 and state attorney general in 2010. In 2016, she became the second black woman and first south-Asian woman elected to the Senate.

There’s been a spate of recent recognition for Chisholm’s ground breaking career, including plans for a Brooklyn statue in her honor.

Updated at 7.27pm GMT

7.16pm GMT

Senator Kamala Harris has just finished her first press conference as a 2020 candidate for president. Here are some highlights from the Howard University event.

The first question was about her role as California attorney general defending the prison system’s policies denying reassignment surgery to transgender inmates. She said:

It was an office with a lot of people and I wish sometimes that they had consulted with me ... I worked behind the scenes to ensure that the department of corrections would allow transitioning inmates to receive the medical attention that they required, that they needed, that they deserved.”

Harris dodged a direct question about whether she believes trans inmates should have access to gender reassignment surgery, saying, “I believe that we are at a point where we have got to stop vilifying people based on sexual orientation. And we’ve got to understand that when we are talking about ... the transgender community, for too long they’ve been the subject of bias and frankly a lack of understanding about their circumstance and their physical needs.”

Asked about Donald Trump and Syria, she said:

We cannot conduct our foreign policy through tweets. My concern is that when we make decisions about what we will do in terms of our military presence ... that we do that in a way that will involve consultation with our military leaders.”

On voter outreach:

For all voters, we’ve got to reach out to folks, we’ve got to go where they are, understand who they are, we have to listen as much as we talk. That is certainly what I intend to do as a candidate ... It is my full intention to travel this country, and to sit in living rooms and to listen to families ... The vast majority of us have so much more in common than what separates us.

One reporter asked, “You’re an African American woman, but you’re also Indian American. I’m just curious how do you describe yourself?”

She responded, “I describe myself as a proud American.”

On the investigations into Trump and Russia:

My highest priority and what I believe should be the highest priority for the United States Congress is that Bob Mueller be able to finish his investigation ... Clearly he is following the facts where they lead him, and there should be no interference with that process, because the American public has a right to know what actually went on.

Asked if she had regrets about her work as a prosecutor, she said:

I can tell you of cases where I really regret that we were not able to charge somebody that I knew molested a child ... There are cases ... where there were folks who made a decision in my office and had not consulted me and I wish they had. But again I take full responsibility for those decisions. But I will also say that there is a lot about what I did as a prosecutor that I’m proud of, including a recognition that there are fundamental flaws in the criminal justice system ... One of my biggest regrets is that I haven’t had time to do more.

On the shutdown:

He’s now holding the American people hostage over a vanity project that he calls a wall while 800,000 people are trying to figure out how they are going to pay their rent, how they’re going to pay their mortgage ... Those folks don’t want a wall. They want a paycheck.”

7.11pm GMT

Senator Kirsten Gillibrand said she feels “called to do what’s right” as she kicks off her presidential bid.

“Only what’s right can defeat what is wrong, and I feel very called at this moment to do what is right,” the New York Democrat said at Rev. Al Sharpton’s Martin Luther King Jr. Day celebration in Harlem.

Gillibrand, who announced her run last week, said white people have the responsibility to participate in the fight against racism.

“It cannot be left to people of color alone. It is wrong to ask men and women of color to bear these burdens every single day,” she said. “White women like me must bear part of this burden.”

“We have to join you on the battle field of justice for all,” she added. “It is my fight. It has to be my fight.”

Gillibrand said Donald Trump has “chosen to tear this country apart.”

“Every racial line, every religious line - he chooses to divide us, community by community. He has inspired a hate and a darkness in this country that I have never witnessed myself,” she said. “That is what we are being called to fight against.”

Gillibrand quoted the book of Ephesians, saying, “We have to put on the full armor of God” to fight against injustice.

Sharpton quipped it was quite a contrast with Trump, who when asked about his favorite verses in the Bible said the whole thing is incredible.

“And you have a candidate that can quote the Bible to Bible people. I don’t know whether the president knows where Ephesians is,” he said.

Updated at 7.14pm GMT

6.34pm GMT

Senator and presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren welcomed her fellow Senator Kamala Harris to the race, calling the competition “terrific” for the country.

“I like hearing the core issues that we should be debating in this country, and drawing the contrast between the Democrats and Donald Trump. That’s what we do every day,” Warren told reporters after speaking at a Martin Luther King Jr. memorial breakfast at the Boston Convention & Exhibition Center, the Boston Globe reported.

6.22pm GMT

Senator Cory Booker declared he is “dissatisfied” and urged the crowd to translate their dissatisfaction into action in a Martin Luther King Jr day speech in South Carolina.

“We are dissatisfied that we live in a nation that finds it easy to take part in dropping million dollar bombs, but can’t take care of veterans right here at home,” the New Jersey Democrat and potential 2020 presidential candidate said. “We are dissatisfied that we live in a nation that finds all the money it needs for tax breaks and for military expeditions but can’t even pay a public school teacher a living wage.”

Booker spoke at the South Carolina NAACP’s MLK day event at the state capitol, where Senator Bernie Sanders also appeared.

“This is not a time for us to rest in our country. The work is not done,” Booker said. “Let us swear the oath that in this nation, there will finally be a day that we are free at last and justice will roll down like water and righteousness like a mighty stream.”

Updated at 6.34pm GMT

6.14pm GMT

The Rev Al Sharpton hit Donald Trump’s brief “drive-by” visit to the Martin Luther King Jr memorial Monday.

Sharpton, at a breakfast earlier Monday in Washington, attacked Trump for failing to have any public events to mark the holiday, calling it an “insult”. Trump then made an unscheduled two-minute stop at the memorial.

“He went by a drive-by of the King memorial, a 90-second stop, which is the epitome of an insult,” Sharpton said at a second MLK event Monday afternoon at his National Action Network headquarters in New York.

“We don’t want a drive-by, Mr. President. We want government open, and to honor Dr. King you should address the government workers,” Sharpton said. “This is the most insensitive president we’ve seen in our life time.”

“Let me tell you something, Martin Luther King holiday is not a day of talking about going shopping for King Day sales, nor is it a day to go drive by a memorial. It’s a day to deal with justice,” Sharpton went on. “There could be nothing more offensive to the legacy of Martin Luther King than to have 800,000 federal workers get no pay.”

Updated at 6.32pm GMT

6.00pm GMT

Senator Bernie Sanders in a Martin Luther King Jr day event in South Carolina called Donald Trump a racist who is looking to “divide us up by the color of our skin, by our gender, by the country we came from, by our religion”.

Sanders, a Vermont senator and potential presidential contender, spoke at the NAACP’s King Day at the Dome event outside the South Carolina state house.

“It gives me no pleasure to tell you that we now have a president of the United States who is a racist,” he said.

“Racism is here,” he said repeatedly, citing gentrification that has pushed out black tenants and homeowners, black schools that are overcrowded and staffed with less experienced teachers, voter suppression, and the fact that 34% of black children live in poverty.

Sanders repeated his calls for Medicare for all, free public college, and universal affordable child care.

He noted that when King was killed, he was in Memphis supporting striking sanitation workers. He “understood not only that we need to end racism, but that we need economic justice,” Sander said.

“King had a revolutionary spirit. Yes, he was a revolutionary,” he said. “We are here to fill his revolutionary spirit.”

Updated at 6.34pm GMT

5.32pm GMT

Senator Joe Manchin, a centrist Democrat and frequent swing vote, is undecided on Donald Trump’s proposed deal to trade temporary protections for young immigrants for money for a border wall.

“He needs to see the final proposal before he decides,” spokesman Jonathan Kott told Politico.

Most Democrats have rejected the proposal which Trump announced on Saturday. Republican Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell is expected to bring it up for a vote on the Senate floor.

5.27pm GMT

Donald Trump mocks House Democrats and encourages his own party to take back the House in 2020 in a tweet today.

5.25pm GMT

Donald Trump and Vice-President Mike Pence made a two-minute visit Monday to Washington’s Martin Luther King Jr Memorial.

They laid a wreath to honor King, Politico reports.

Trump had faced criticism after his public schedule included no events marking the King holiday.

Updated at 6.33pm GMT

5.21pm GMT

Many voters in Michigan who backed Donald Trump are fed up with him over the government shutdown, the Washington Post reports.

Trump voters said he had gone too far by forcing a government shutdown because Democrats would not agree to more than $5 billion to pay for a border wall.

“It’s silly. It’s destructive,” Jeff Daudert, 49, told the paper.

5.13pm GMT

TSA absentee rate hits 10%

Some 10% of Transportation Security Administration agents were absent on Sunday, the highest rate since the government shutdown began.

The 10% unscheduled absence rate is more than triple the 3.1% rate on the same day a year ago, the agency said in a statement Monday. “Many employees are reporting that they are not able to report to work due to financial limitations,” the TSA said.

TSA screeners are among 800,000 federal workers not getting paid during a partial federal government shutdown.

The TSA said that 99.9% of passengers waited less than 30 minutes for security, which the TSA considers normal though it is longer than passengers are accustomed to waiting. At Louis Armstrong New Orleans International Airport, the wait time was up to 45 minutes.

Updated at 5.18pm GMT

5.03pm GMT

Republican senators may use the so-called “nuclear option” to push through Donald Trump’s judicial nominees, Sen. Todd Young said Monday.

Lower-level judge nominations that lack 60 votes are subject to 30 hours of debate in the Senate, which Democrats have used to slow down approvals, frustrating Republicans. Young, an Indiana Republican, told the Hugh Hewitt radio show that the Senate may move soon to allow debate to be ended with a simple majority.

“It’s very difficult for a president to advance his or her agenda if you don’t have the right people in place,” he said. “This is just a personnel issue. We want to make sure that the right people, whether they’re judges or mid-level appointees to different agencies are expeditiously processed if they are of a non-controversial nature.”

It is already possible to confirm Supreme Court nominees with a 51-vote majority, after the rules were changed to end the filibuster for those confirmations.

4.52pm GMT

Senators Cory Booker and Bernie Sanders marched from the Zion Baptist Church to the South Carolina State House with the NAACP and other groups, where they are participating in the “King Day at the Dome” event, according to the Associated Press.

The two politicians, both potential 2020 presidential candidates, looked to be working the room as a team at the church.

4.46pm GMT

Senator Jeff Merkley said Monday he asked the FBI to investigate the secretary of Homeland Security for perjury because he is “sick and tired of this administration lying to the American people.”

Merkley, of Oregon, requested Friday that the FBI investigate whether DHS secretary Kirstjen Nielsen lied in sworn testimony to Congress about the Trump administration’s policy of separating immigrant children from their parents.

He released a 2017 memo from Homeland Security and Justice Department officials in which they listed “separate family units” as a potential immigration policy, predicting that such a policy would have a deterrent effect on immigrants seeking to cross the border. But Nielsen told Congress in testimony under oath that there was never a policy to separate families.

“I am just sick and tired of this administration lying to the American people, lying to Congress, doing it under oath,” Merkley said Monday on CNN’s New Day. “And it’s time for some real accountability.”

He said the FBI had not responded to his request. “This is the official, right way to initiate a referral to the FBI for pursuit of an investigation regarding perjury,” he said.

4.24pm GMT

Biden in MLK day speech: "It doesn't take much to awaken hate"

Former Vice-President Joe Biden said Monday that Donald Trump’s time as president has taught him that “it doesn’t take much to awaken hate.”

Speaking at the National Action Network’s Martin Luther King Jr. Day breakfast, Biden, who is considering a presidential run, seized on a quote from King that could serve as a counter to Trump’s “Make America great again” slogan: “Make America what is ought to be.”

“We’ve learned in the last two years it doesn’t take much to awaken hate, to bring those folks out from under the rocks, that part of American society that’s always been there, will always be there,” Biden said, addressing King’s son. “Fifty years later, the hate that cut your dad down is still nurtured by those forces of darkness.”

“They have been deliberately reawakened again, those forces. It’s not an accident,” Biden said, citing the white supremacist protests in Charlottesville. “We have to challenge those forces of hate and stand up and simply say what the vast majority of Americans agree to: This is not our America.”

Biden went on to call for an end to mandatory prison sentences at the state level, ending cash bail, a $15 minimum wage, and a prohibition on non-compete agreements that stop workers from taking jobs.

“Folks, what the hell are we arguing about a $15 minimum wage for? Why is it even a question? No, no, really. Below that rate you’re at the poverty level - people working and busting their necks,” he said.

Biden said black Americans have been systematically disadvantaged in criminal justice, education, healthcare and housing.

“There’s systematic racism that most of us whites don’t like to acknowledge even exists,” he said. “There’s something we have to admit - not you, we, white America, has to admit there’s still a systematic racism and it goes almost unnoticed by so many of us.”

Updated at 4.55pm GMT

3.49pm GMT

Former Starbucks CEO Howard Schultz is considering running for president in 2020 as an independent, CNN reports.

A source told the network his allies are “are exploring a possible independent bid for the presidency in 2020,” and that Schultz “is thinking deeply about his future and how he can best serve the country.”

Schultz stepped down from the top job at Starbucks last year and said at the time he would consider running for president, harshly criticizing Donald Trump.

“Anyone thinking of running for president as an independent would have to think really hard about splitting the anti-incumbent, anti-Trump vote and just playing the spoiler role and reelecting Trump,” Howard Wolfson, who is advising former New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg on his potential campaign as a Democrat, told the Washington Post, which reported on Friday that Schultz was considering a bid.

3.37pm GMT

The Rev Al Sharpton slammed Donald Trump for not holding an event to honor Martin Luther King Jr. Day.

Sharpton called it an “insult,” the New York Daily News reported. He was speaking at his organization’s MLK Day breakfast in Washington DC, where potential presidential contenders Joe Biden and Mike Bloomberg appeared.

“Today as we have this breakfast, there is no official event at the White House to celebrate Martin Luther King Day,” Sharpton said.

“The vice president... nor the President, have any official thing on their calendar to celebrate a federal holiday that Ronald Reagan signed,” he added. “This is an insult to the American people that the president of the United States does not officially recognize or give any ceremony for Dr King.”

Updated at 4.55pm GMT

3.30pm GMT

Former New York mayor Michael Bloomberg spoke at the National Action Network’s MLK day breakfast in Washington, where he was joined by former Vice-President Joe Biden.

“Whatever the next year brings for Joe and me, we will keep our eye on the prize – electing a Democrat in 2020,” he said, according to the LA Times. This would be an unremarkable statement for most potential Democratic presidential candidates, but it’s notable for Bloomberg, who has always said he voted based on the person, not party.

Bloomberg did not mention stop and frisk - which Rev. Al Sharpton did bring up during his introduction - according to CNN. But he did say he “can’t stand up here and tell you every decision I have made as mayor was perfect.”

Bloomberg, known for his advocacy of gun control, said King would have been proud of the gun control movement, according to the LA Times. “I have never seen more energy behind the movement than I see right now,” he said.

He said there was “no doubt” that if King had lived, he would have made gun violence a key part of his fight, according to NBC News.

Bloomberg said King would have been “especially proud” of the election of Lucy McBath, a new Georgia congresswoman who became a gun control advocate after her son was shot and killed, according to the Atlantic. Bloomberg noted he helped pay for ads for her.

Bloomberg also touted his education record as mayor, noting the education budget in New York City doubled during his tenure, according to NBC News. He said that if Dr King saw “the little progress we’ve made in giving all minority children a sufficient education to succeed over the past four years, he would be shocked”.

Updated at 3.44pm GMT

3.08pm GMT

The Rev Al Sharpton, introducing former New York Mayor Mike Bloomberg at his breakfast in Washington, said: “We disagreed on Stop and Frisk but we agreed on education,” per NYT.

Sharpton is referring to stop and frisk practiced by the NYPD, who under Bloomberg as mayor stopped and searched thousands of mostly black and Latino men. Bloomberg staunchly defended the policy as necessary to keep crime down, but crime remained low when the number of stops plummeted under Bloomberg’s successor Bill de Blasio. It’s expected to be one of his major liabilities of Bloomberg runs for president in the Democratic party.

Bloomberg was also a big booster of charter schools. It’s a stance he shares with Sharpton and many other prominent Democrats, but many in the party have been moving in the other direction recently.

Updated at 3.44pm GMT

2.53pm GMT

As the US observes Martin Luther King Jr day, potential Democratic candidates are appearing at several events honoring the civil rights hero.

Former vice president Joe Biden and former New York Mayor Mike Bloomberg are at the National Action Network’s MLK Day Breakfast in Washington, DC.

Senators Cory Booker and Bernie Sanders are at the Zion Baptist Church, in Columbia, South Carolina, according to the New York Times.

Booker and Sanders are also set to participate in the South Carolina NAACP’s King Day at the Dome event, walking with the group to the South Carolina state house.

Senator Kirsten Gillibrand is among those speaking at Rev. Al Sharpton’s MLK Day celebration at his National Action Network headquarters in Harlem, where New York Mayor Bill de Blasio will also speak.

Former Georgia gubernatorial candidate Stacey Abrams is holding a kickoff event for a “Thank You Tour” thanking her supporters.

Updated at 3.50pm GMT

2.44pm GMT

Secretary of State Mike Pompeo is considering a run for Senate in Kansas and met Sunday with leading GOP consultant Ward Baker, Politico reports.

Kansas Senator Pat Roberts, a Republican, announced that he won’t be running for re-election in 2020.

2.33pm GMT

As the Coast Guard Cutter Bertholf departed for a months-long deployment in the Indo-Pacific, Coast Guard commandant Admiral Karl Schultz made nod to the fact that its crew members are not getting paid because of the government shutdown.

“I know it’s hard for these crews to be leaving behind their dependants and spouses. It’s a thousand times more so when everyone is wondering when their next paycheck will be, and how they can support the family that they are leaving behind,” vice admiral Linda Fagan, commander of the Coast Guard Pacific area, added in a video.

“The tension and the anxiety for the crew is real.”

2.22pm GMT

Senator Kamala Harris, in New York to announce her presidential campaign on ABC’s Good Morning America, celebrated with an egg and cheese sandwich at a shop in Penn Station, according to a photo posted by her communications director.

Updated at 2.32pm GMT

2.11pm GMT

A large majority of freshman Democrats in the House do not yet support impeaching Donald Trump, Axios reports. The news site contacted all 64 new Democrats, and only six said they support impeaching Trump. The largest group, 48 lawmakers, said Congress should wait for special counsel Robert Mueller to complete his investigation before considering impeachment.

2.07pm GMT

Senator Kamala Harris will hold her first campaign event Friday in South Carolina, where black voters are a dominant force in the Democratic primary, the New York Times reports - rather than kicking off with trips to Iowa and New Hampshire, which hold the first caucus and primary.

She plans to hold a kickoff rally Sunday in Oakland, her home town. Harris was the second black woman to become a US Senator. She is the daughter of an Indian mother and Jamaican father who met in Berkeley, California, at the height of the civil rights movement.

Updated at 3.01pm GMT

1.58pm GMT

Senator Kamala Harris announces run for president

California Senator Kamala Harris officially launched her campaign for president this morning.

“Let’s do this, together. Let’s claim our future. For ourselves, for our children, and for our country,” Harris said in a campaign video.

She joined a field that already includes Senators Elizabeth Warren and Kirsten Gillibrand, and former housing secretary Julián Castro, among others.

Read more about her announcement here, and the debate among progressives about her work as a prosecutor here.

Updated at 2.07pm GMT
fields.bodyText: We’re wrapping now. These are today’s key politics stories. California Senator Kamala Harris announced her campaign for president. Official and potential 2020 contenders delivered lofty speeches at events marking Martin Luther King Jr. Day. Meanwhile, Donald Trump made a two-minute visit to the MLK monument in Washington, and the civil rights hero’s son criticized vice-president Mike Pence for invoking his dad in making the case for a border wall. The TSA said that a record-high one in ten of its agents did not show up for work Sunday, as the government shutdown continued through its 30th day. We’ll be back tomorrow with more live coverage. Until then, you can sign up to receive our US morning briefing for a summary of the day’s top stories and must-reads. The Guardian’s Hubert Adjei-Kontoh reports: At a packed Harlem church this afternoon congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez sat down with the award-winning writer Ta-Nehisi Coates at an event marking Martin Luther King’s legacy. Ocasio-Cortez rejected Donald Trump’s latest proposal to trade temporary protections for young immigrants for money for a border wall, saying there was no reason to give $5 billion to an “unstable person.” The new Congresswoman also touted her proposal to tax the richest Americans at a 70% marginal rate, an idea that was warmly received at the event at Riverside Church. Asked if she was considering running for president (which would have to wait until 2024, since she’s too young to run in 2020), Ocasio-Cortez said she was not, arguing that the fixation on higher office “prevents people from speaking truth to power.” About those 8,000-plus false and misleading statements from Donald Trump during his presidency: It makes for grueling work for the fact checkers. The Guardian’s Adam Gabbatt reports: Since taking office, the president has lied about everything from immigration figures to the number of burgers he served to the Clemson football team at the White House last week. “It takes up a lot of our time just because he is constantly talking,” said Glenn Kessler, editor and chief writer of the Washington Post’s Fact Checker column. “The pace in Washington has changed. You could wake up and the president may have already had five or six tweets that cry out for fact checks.” Kessler and the Washington Post responded by creating an ongoing database tracking Trump’s lies. But that comes with its own problems. “It’s become an all-consuming task. In the month of October he said 1,200 things that were false or misleading. There’s some days where he’s topped more than 100 false or misleading claims.” The Washington Post has tallied Donald Trump’s untruths, and finds that the president made at least 8,158 false or misleading statements in the two years since he took office. That includes 6,000 such statements in his second year alone, according to the paper’s Fact Checker. That adds up to nearly 5.9 false or misleading claims a day in year one, which went up to 16.5 a year in year two. Martin Luther King III criticized the vice-president for invoking his father’s memory in making the push for a wall along the US-Mexico border. “The hearts and minds of the American people today are thinking a lot about it being the weekend we remember the life and work of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.,” Pence said Sunday on CBS’s “Face the Nation.” “One of my favorite quotes from Dr. King was ‘now is the time to make real the promises of democracy.’ You think of how he changed America,” he said. “He inspired us to change through the legislative process to become a more perfect union. That’s exactly what President Trump is calling on the Congress to do: Come to the table in a spirit of good faith. We’ll secure our border, we’ll reopen our government.” King’s son rejected the comparison while speaking at a National Action Network MLK Day breakfast, CNN reported. “Martin Luther King Jr. was a bridge builder, not a wall builder,” he said. “Martin Luther King Jr. would say love not hate would make America great. Did you all hear that? Love not hate would make America great.” Donald Trump did not speak to Michael Cohen before Cohen false testimony to Congress about a Trump Tower project in Moscow, Rudy Giuliani said Monday - the latest reversal from the president’s lawyer. “The President never spoke with Cohen about the congressional testimony,” Giuliani told the New York Daily News. On Sunday, Giuliani told CNN’s “State of the Union” that he wasn’t sure whether Trump talked to Cohen about his testimony. “So what if he talked to him about it?” he said. The Guardian’s Max Benwell reports: In a conversation with writer Ta-Nehisi Coates at Harlem’s Riverside Church, Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez discussed her tendency to shoot down critics on social media. “Whoever is coming at me in my mentions with a blue check when I haven’t eaten in three hours ... Until more people start pitching in and holding people to account, I’m just going to let them have it,” she said. White House press secretary Sarah Sanders has drawn some backlash for a tweet saying that Martin Luther King Jr “gave his life to right the wrong of racial inequality.” Writer Ta-Nehisi Coates is interviewing Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez at a Martin Luther King Jr. Day event at Manhattan’s Riverside Church. Rep. Hakeem Jeffries, speaking at the National Action Network MLK Day event, called Donald Trump the “grand wizard of 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue,” a reference to the Ku Klux Klan. Gizmodo finds some evidence that Donald Trump’s team has been posting altered photos to his Facebook and Instagram accounts to make him look thinner and his fingers longer. Senator Kamala Harris entered the crowded Democratic 2020 race for US president with a tribute to a woman who broke barriers in American politics decades earlier. The Guardian’s Sam Levin reports: The California senator’s logo is a nod to Shirley Chisholm, the first woman and African American to seek the nomination for president in a major political party, in 1972. Harris, the former attorney general of California, has chosen a red and yellow design for her logo that resembles the campaign buttons used five decades ago by Chisholm, the first black woman elected to Congress. Harris, the daughter of immigrants from India and Jamaica, has broken barriers throughout her meteoric rise in California politics. The Democrat was the first African American and first woman to be elected San Francisco district attorney in 2003 and state attorney general in 2010. In 2016, she became the second black woman and first south-Asian woman elected to the Senate. There’s been a spate of recent recognition for Chisholm’s ground breaking career, including plans for a Brooklyn statue in her honor. Senator Kamala Harris has just finished her first press conference as a 2020 candidate for president. Here are some highlights from the Howard University event. The first question was about her role as California attorney general defending the prison system’s policies denying reassignment surgery to transgender inmates. She said: It was an office with a lot of people and I wish sometimes that they had consulted with me ... I worked behind the scenes to ensure that the department of corrections would allow transitioning inmates to receive the medical attention that they required, that they needed, that they deserved.” Harris dodged a direct question about whether she believes trans inmates should have access to gender reassignment surgery, saying, “I believe that we are at a point where we have got to stop vilifying people based on sexual orientation. And we’ve got to understand that when we are talking about ... the transgender community, for too long they’ve been the subject of bias and frankly a lack of understanding about their circumstance and their physical needs.” Asked about Donald Trump and Syria, she said: We cannot conduct our foreign policy through tweets. My concern is that when we make decisions about what we will do in terms of our military presence ... that we do that in a way that will involve consultation with our military leaders.” On voter outreach: For all voters, we’ve got to reach out to folks, we’ve got to go where they are, understand who they are, we have to listen as much as we talk. That is certainly what I intend to do as a candidate ... It is my full intention to travel this country, and to sit in living rooms and to listen to families ... The vast majority of us have so much more in common than what separates us. One reporter asked, “You’re an African American woman, but you’re also Indian American. I’m just curious how do you describe yourself?” She responded, “I describe myself as a proud American.” On the investigations into Trump and Russia: My highest priority and what I believe should be the highest priority for the United States Congress is that Bob Mueller be able to finish his investigation ... Clearly he is following the facts where they lead him, and there should be no interference with that process, because the American public has a right to know what actually went on. Asked if she had regrets about her work as a prosecutor, she said: I can tell you of cases where I really regret that we were not able to charge somebody that I knew molested a child ... There are cases ... where there were folks who made a decision in my office and had not consulted me and I wish they had. But again I take full responsibility for those decisions. But I will also say that there is a lot about what I did as a prosecutor that I’m proud of, including a recognition that there are fundamental flaws in the criminal justice system ... One of my biggest regrets is that I haven’t had time to do more. On the shutdown: He’s now holding the American people hostage over a vanity project that he calls a wall while 800,000 people are trying to figure out how they are going to pay their rent, how they’re going to pay their mortgage ... Those folks don’t want a wall. They want a paycheck.” Senator Kirsten Gillibrand said she feels “called to do what’s right” as she kicks off her presidential bid. “Only what’s right can defeat what is wrong, and I feel very called at this moment to do what is right,” the New York Democrat said at Rev. Al Sharpton’s Martin Luther King Jr. Day celebration in Harlem. Gillibrand, who announced her run last week, said white people have the responsibility to participate in the fight against racism. “It cannot be left to people of color alone. It has to be my fight.” Gillibrand said Donald Trump has “chosen to tear this country apart.” “Every racial line, every religious line - he chooses to divide us, community by community. He has inspired a hate and a darkness in this country that I have never witnessed myself,” she said. “That is what we are being called to fight against.” Gillibrand quoted the book of Ephesians, saying, “We have to put on the full armor of God” to fight against injustice. It’s not an accident,” Biden said, citing the white supremacist protests in Charlottesville. “We have to challenge those forces of hate and stand up and simply say what the vast majority of Americans agree to: This is not our America.” Biden went on to call for an end to mandatory prison sentences at the state level, ending cash bail, a $15 minimum wage, and a prohibition on non-compete agreements that stop workers from taking jobs. “Folks, what the hell are we arguing about a $15 minimum wage for? Why is it even a question? No, no, really. Below that rate you’re at the poverty level - people working and busting their necks,” he said. Biden said black Americans have been systematically disadvantaged in criminal justice, education, healthcare and housing. “There’s systematic racism that most of us whites don’t like to acknowledge even exists,” he said. “There’s something we have to admit - not you, we, white America, has to admit there’s still a systematic racism and it goes almost unnoticed by so many of us.” Former Starbucks CEO Howard Schultz is considering running for president in 2020 as an independent, CNN reports. A source told the network his allies are “are exploring a possible independent bid for the presidency in 2020,” and that Schultz “is thinking deeply about his future and how he can best serve the country.” Schultz stepped down from the top job at Starbucks last year and said at the time he would consider running for president, harshly criticizing Donald Trump. “Anyone thinking of running for president as an independent would have to think really hard about splitting the anti-incumbent, anti-Trump vote and just playing the spoiler role and reelecting Trump,” Howard Wolfson, who is advising former New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg on his potential campaign as a Democrat, told the Washington Post, which reported on Friday that Schultz was considering a bid. The Rev Al Sharpton slammed Donald Trump for not holding an event to honor Martin Luther King Jr. Day. Sharpton called it an “insult,” the New York Daily News reported. He was speaking at his organization’s MLK Day breakfast in Washington DC, where potential presidential contenders Joe Biden and Mike Bloomberg appeared. “Today as we have this breakfast, there is no official event at the White House to celebrate Martin Luther King Day,” Sharpton said. “The vice president... nor the President, have any official thing on their calendar to celebrate a federal holiday that Ronald Reagan signed,” he added. “This is an insult to the American people that the president of the United States does not officially recognize or give any ceremony for Dr King.” Former New York mayor Michael Bloomberg spoke at the National Action Network’s MLK day breakfast in Washington, where he was joined by former Vice-President Joe Biden. “Whatever the next year brings for Joe and me, we will keep our eye on the prize – electing a Democrat in 2020,” he said, according to the LA Times. This would be an unremarkable statement for most potential Democratic presidential candidates, but it’s notable for Bloomberg, who has always said he voted based on the person, not party. Bloomberg did not mention stop and frisk - which Rev. Al Sharpton did bring up during his introduction - according to CNN. But he did say he “can’t stand up here and tell you every decision I have made as mayor was perfect.” Bloomberg, known for his advocacy of gun control, said King would have been proud of the gun control movement, according to the LA Times. “I have never seen more energy behind the movement than I see right now,” he said. He said there was “no doubt” that if King had lived, he would have made gun violence a key part of his fight, according to NBC News. Bloomberg said King would have been “especially proud” of the election of Lucy McBath, a new Georgia congresswoman who became a gun control advocate after her son was shot and killed, according to the Atlantic. Bloomberg noted he helped pay for ads for her. Bloomberg also touted his education record as mayor, noting the education budget in New York City doubled during his tenure, according to NBC News. He said that if Dr King saw “the little progress we’ve made in giving all minority children a sufficient education to succeed over the past four years, he would be shocked”. The Rev Al Sharpton, introducing former New York Mayor Mike Bloomberg at his breakfast in Washington, said: “We disagreed on Stop and Frisk but we agreed on education,” per NYT. Sharpton is referring to stop and frisk practiced by the NYPD, who under Bloomberg as mayor stopped and searched thousands of mostly black and Latino men. Bloomberg staunchly defended the policy as necessary to keep crime down, but crime remained low when the number of stops plummeted under Bloomberg’s successor Bill de Blasio. It’s expected to be one of his major liabilities of Bloomberg runs for president in the Democratic party. Bloomberg was also a big booster of charter schools. It’s a stance he shares with Sharpton and many other prominent Democrats, but many in the party have been moving in the other direction recently. As the US observes Martin Luther King Jr day, potential Democratic candidates are appearing at several events honoring the civil rights hero. Former vice president Joe Biden and former New York Mayor Mike Bloomberg are at the National Action Network’s MLK Day Breakfast in Washington, DC. Senators Cory Booker and Bernie Sanders are at the Zion Baptist Church, in Columbia, South Carolina, according to the New York Times. Booker and Sanders are also set to participate in the South Carolina NAACP’s King Day at the Dome event, walking with the group to the South Carolina state house. Senator Kirsten Gillibrand is among those speaking at Rev. Al Sharpton’s MLK Day celebration at his National Action Network headquarters in Harlem, where New York Mayor Bill de Blasio will also speak. Former Georgia gubernatorial candidate Stacey Abrams is holding a kickoff event for a “Thank You Tour” thanking her supporters. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo is considering a run for Senate in Kansas and met Sunday with leading GOP consultant Ward Baker, Politico reports. Kansas Senator Pat Roberts, a Republican, announced that he won’t be running for re-election in 2020. As the Coast Guard Cutter Bertholf departed for a months-long deployment in the Indo-Pacific, Coast Guard commandant Admiral Karl Schultz made nod to the fact that its crew members are not getting paid because of the government shutdown. “I know it’s hard for these crews to be leaving behind their dependants and spouses. It’s a thousand times more so when everyone is wondering when their next paycheck will be, and how they can support the family that they are leaving behind,” vice admiral Linda Fagan, commander of the Coast Guard Pacific area, added in a video. “The tension and the anxiety for the crew is real.” Senator Kamala Harris, in New York to announce her presidential campaign on ABC’s Good Morning America, celebrated with an egg and cheese sandwich at a shop in Penn Station, according to a photo posted by her communications director. A large majority of freshman Democrats in the House do not yet support impeaching Donald Trump, Axios reports. The news site contacted all 64 new Democrats, and only six said they support impeaching Trump. The largest group, 48 lawmakers, said Congress should wait for special counsel Robert Mueller to complete his investigation before considering impeachment. Senator Kamala Harris will hold her first campaign event Friday in South Carolina, where black voters are a dominant force in the Democratic primary, the New York Times reports - rather than kicking off with trips to Iowa and New Hampshire, which hold the first caucus and primary. She plans to hold a kickoff rally Sunday in Oakland, her home town. Harris was the second black woman to become a US Senator. She is the daughter of an Indian mother and Jamaican father who met in Berkeley, California, at the height of the civil rights movement. California Senator Kamala Harris officially launched her campaign for president this morning. “Let’s do this, together. Let’s claim our future. For ourselves, for our children, and for our country,” Harris said in a campaign video. She joined a field that already includes Senators Elizabeth Warren and Kirsten Gillibrand, and former housing secretary Julián Castro, among others. Read more about her announcement here, and the debate among progressives about her work as a prosecutor here.

webTitle: Avon apologizes for anti-cellulite ad after being accused of 'shaming women'

fields.headline: Avon apologizes for anti-cellulite ad after being accused of 'shaming women'
fields.standfirst: Avon responded to actor’s criticism: ‘We realize that we missed the mark with this messaging. We have removed this messaging’
fields.trailText: Avon responded to actor’s criticism: ‘We realize that we missed the mark with this messaging. We have removed this messaging’
fields.body:
Cosmetics giant Avon USA has apologized for an anti-cellulite product after the ad campaign was accused of “shaming women”.

Actor Jameela Jamil had criticized the ad, which features a seated woman in shorts and tank top with the caption “dimples are cute on your face (not on your thighs),” on Saturday afternoon on Twitter.

“And yet EVERYONE has dimples on their thighs, I do, you do, and the CLOWNS at @Avon_UK certainly do. Stop shaming women about age, gravity and cellulite. They’re inevitable, completely normal things. To make us fear them and try to ‘fix’ them, is to literally set us up for failure.”

The Good Place actor criticized another ad for the company’s “Naked Proof” line of cosmetics, which leads with the phrase “Every body is beautiful,” several hours later.

“Every body is beautiful, unless they have any ‘flaws’ I guess. What a gross abuse of the body positive movement. I want you all to look out for this constant manipulation. Once you see it, you can’t unsee it. It’s everywhere. You are constantly being manipulated to self hate,” said Jamil, who is behind the “I Weigh” movement to promote body positivity.

Avon responded to Jamil’s criticism just after 5pm, tweeting, “Hi Jameela, we completely understand where you’re coming from. We realize that we missed the mark with this messaging. We have removed this messaging from all future marketing materials. We fully support our community in loving their bodies and feel confident in their own skin.”

“THIS RIGHT HERE IS PROGRESS!!!! Thank you @AvonInsider for listening to us,” she responded.

Avon USA also tweeted: “We hear you and we apologize. We messed up on our Smooth Moves Naked Proof messaging. We want to let you know that we are working diligently to remove this messaging from our marketing materials moving forward. We’re on it. We love our community of women.”

webTitle: Yellow crazy ant invasion threatens Queensland world heritage rainforest as funding dries up

fields.headline: Yellow crazy ant invasion threatens Queensland world heritage rainforest as funding dries up
fields.standfirst: Program holding ants at bay in wet tropics suffers from lack of government funding commitment
fields.trailText: Program holding ants at bay in planet’s oldest continuing rainforest suffers from lack of government funding commitment
fields.body:
Funding to keep a voracious invasive ant from establishing super colonies in Australia’s wet tropics world heritage area has less than six months of funding left, risking its future, Guardian Australia has been told.

The Wet Tropics Management Authority (WTMA), which manages the vast world heritage area in north Queensland, is asking state and federal governments for a $6m a year package for the next seven years – enough, the authority says, for it to finish the job of eradicating the yellow crazy ant.

Related: 'We are clearly losing the fight': scientists sound alarm over invasive species

Yellow crazy ants have long been considered one of the world’s worst invasive species. The ants, which spit formic acid, build super colonies that transform native habitats, overwhelming small species.

On Christmas Island, the ants have killed millions of the island’s unique red crabs, transforming areas of the forest floor.

The wet tropics are considered the world’s oldest continuing rainforest and a “living museum” of ancient plants and animals.

Scott Buchanan, the authority’s executive director, said: “If we were to see the sort of degradation that these ants have caused on Christmas Island, then that would have a significant impact not only on the world heritage values of the wet tropics, but also on the tourism industry and the quality of life of all the people who live here.

“We continue to talk to the state and commonwealth, but at this stage while we’ve had positive indications, there has been no commitment. It’s now cutting things fine.

“If we were forced to walk away from this, then we have some preliminary modelling that shows that within 20 years the ants would cover a significant part of this world heritage area.”

A 2017 review of the wet tropics by the United Nations world heritage committee said the ants posed “a real and significant threat to the world heritage values of the wet tropics over the longer term” with more effort and funding needed to be effective.

The authority’s program started in 2013 with a $2m federal government grant. In 2016, the authority’s ant program got $3.04m from the Queensland government and $7.5m from the federal government.

But that money will run out in June and with less than six months to go, the authority is making contingency plans if its funding requests are not met, or funding is delayed.

The authority is asking for $6m per year for the next seven years and hopes the Queensland and federal governments will agree to split the cost.

Related: Cane toads snake ride on python's back to escape storm in northern Australia

“With that, it would get us to the endgame which is the eradication of these ants in and near the world heritage area,” said Buchanan.

Twenty-eight field and support staff work on the program, together with contractors, including a five-strong Aboriginal ranger group helping with survey and treatment work.

“Those 28 people are on temporary rolling contracts so even before June, they’re going to need to look elsewhere as things become more uncertain.”

He said several of the field staff had come through the federal government’s “green army” program and had previously been long-term unemployed.

“They have become very competent field operators. They are able to work in very rough terrain and in quite extreme conditions. We’ve invested in those people and it would be a real shame to lose them.”

The program targets the ants with small doses of an insecticide – fipronil – mixed with fishmeal, which worker ants collect and feed to a queen, causing a colony to collapse.

The infestation of ants occurs in pockets south of Cairns and encroaching into the world heritage area, with another small area in the village of Kuranda to the north.

Larger ant areas away from waterways and homes are targeted with helicopter drops, but at other sites the fishmeal is placed by hand.

Peter Green of La Trobe University discovered the Christmas Island ants in 1997 and has researched them ever since. He said: “Let’s not find out what these ants could do.”

While the impacts of the ants on an area such as the wet tropics were not well studied, “there’s enough in the scientific literature to say that while we might not know exactly what the impacts are, that this program [to eradicate the ants] should proceed”.

Lori Lach, an ecologist at James Cook University, provides scientific advice to the eradication program. She said: “What’s at stake here? Well, the wet tropics world heritage area has 56% of Australia’s butterfly species, 40% of birds, 42% freshwater fish, 30% of the mammal species … and the list goes on and on. This is a fight that we really don’t want to lose.”

In a statement, the Queensland’s environment minister, Leeanne Enoch said the Palaszczuk government recognised the work of the WTMA in eradicating yellow crazy ants.

Enoch met with the authority in December 2018 to “discuss their schedule of works and associated funding” and look[ed] forward to discussing again “in the near future”.

She added: “Any funding allocation will be determined as part of the normal government budget process.”

Guardian Australia also has requested comment from federal environment minister Melissa Price.

  • This article was amended to include the statement from Queensland’s environment department after it was provided

webTitle: Wasps scrum-half Dan Robson to stake England claim with overdue first cap

fields.headline: Wasps scrum-half Dan Robson to stake England claim with overdue first cap
fields.standfirst:
• Robson is one of only two scrum-halves in Six Nations squad
• ‘Hopefully in the next couple of weeks I can cement my place’
fields.trailText: As one of only two scrum-halves in Eddie Jones’s Six Nations squad, Wasps’ Dan Robson should finally win an England cap that has been a long time coming
fields.body:
For a sense of just how long overdue Dan Robson’s first England cap is, Dai Young’s explanation for taking him off in the latter stages of Wasps’ defeat by Leinster on Sunday is revealing. “I wouldn’t live with myself if he got a bump in the last 12 minutes.”

Granted Wasps’ European campaign was long since over at the point Robson made way but Young is in the majority in thinking his scrum-half’s international debut ought to have come some time ago. It would probably have arrived last autumn, only for an ankle injury to rule him out of England’s entire campaign, but as one of only two scrum-halves in Eddie Jones’s Six Nations squad it will surely come against Ireland.

Related: Danny Cipriani waiting on England call after Owen Farrell hand surgery

It is some show of faith from Jones to leave out both Danny Care and Richard Wigglesworth because Robson was little more than a passenger when selected for last summer’s tour of South Africa. “It is a nice vote of confidence when there are only two of you. I haven’t been involved like that yet, so it will be good to get some reps over the next fortnight and put my hand up,” said Robson, who revealed he learned of his call-up last Thursday morning from his partner Liz. “I was still half-asleep. It was a nice way to wake up.

“Good things don’t come easy. It’s part of the journey I’ve had to go through. It has been frustrating but Eddie has seen stuff I need to work on; my time wasn’t right. But hopefully in the next couple of weeks I can get on the field and really cement my place.”

With Care omitted, the Six Nations represents Robson’s chance to convince Jones he is at least his go-to bench option behind Ben Youngs. It has taken the Wasps scrum-half a long time to emerge from Jones’s blind spot but to his credit he has done so by staying true to his livewire style of play. “I’ve always stuck to my guns, tried to play attacking rugby and always back myself,” said Robson. “I feel like I’ve been doing that still. I have bided my time a lot and for me it is about getting an opportunity and nailing it down.”

Related: Warren Gatland may coach in Premiership again after Wales farewell

Jones was in the stands to watch Robson’s performance against Leinster and a tranche of Ireland players who will face England on 2 February. He will have been impressed by Robson’s second-half try but perhaps more so that he was able to impress behind a pack that came off second best. “All big European games are another notch up. It’s probably the closest thing you can get to international rugby without playing it,” said Robson. “As a No 9 it’s easy to get going when you’re on the front foot all the time. When you’re on the back foot, you’ve got to do things differently.”

Jones, meanwhile, has been boosted with the news Joe Launchbury is recovering well from the neck injury sustained on Sunday while he is still mulling over whether to add fly-half cover for the forthcoming training camp in Portugal in light of Owen Farrell’s thumb surgery. Ireland have mounting problems in the second row with Munster’s Tadhg Beirne out of the first two rounds of the Six Nations with a knee injury and Iain Henderson set for several weeks on the sidelines with a finger injury. Hamish Watson has dropped out of Scotland’s squad with a hand injury.

webTitle: Warren Gatland may coach in Premiership again after Wales farewell

fields.headline: Warren Gatland may coach in Premiership again after Wales farewell
fields.standfirst:
• ‘I have had a couple of discussions,’ says Wales head coach
• Gatland enjoyed success coaching Wasps in 2000s
fields.trailText: Warren Gatland has held discussions about his next full-time job after Wales in the World Cup and has not ruled out a return to the Premiership
fields.body:
Warren Gatland, who ends his 12-year association with Wales at the end of the World Cup, has held discussions about his next full-time job and has not ruled out a return to the Premiership where he enjoyed a trophy-rich period with Wasps in the 2000s.

Gatland is preparing for his final Six Nations as Wales head coach. He had intended to take a few months off after the World Cup before deciding his future but, as a coach with a winning record at Wasps, Waikato and Wales, he was always going to be sounded out early. As one of the highest paid coaches in the world, he will not come cheap but Premiership clubs come armed with cash from a private equity company.

Related: Danny Cipriani waiting on England call after Owen Farrell hand surgery

“I have had a couple of discussions with some people at the moment but there is definitely nothing concrete,” said Gatland. “Maybe at the end of the World Cup I’ll be unemployed. I was considering taking a few months off and then start looking in the middle of 2020, seeing if there was an opportunity do so some Super Rugby in New Zealand. If there was, I would probably go back there and do that.

“There are not a lot of jobs in New Zealand so the option could be in club rugby in the Premiership or France or Japan. There is a lot to come before I have to decide and I am really excited about my last Six Nations with Wales. It is a big year and you have got to be up for it. I think we will do well and I am really looking forward to it.”

Should he be appointed in the Premiership or Top 14, he would not be released to the Lions as head coach, with reports over the weekend suggesting he is in the frame to reprise the role for a third time. Having overseen a victorious series in Australia and historic draw in New Zealand. Gatland was quoted as saying he had held “informal conversations” over the tour to South Africa in 2021, when what were supposed to be off-the-record remarks at a dinner found their way into the public domain.

Related: Wasps scrum-half Dan Robson to stake England claim with overdue first cap

Gatland has been coaching full-time for 25 years but only four of those were spent in his native New Zealand, with Thames Valley at the outside and Waikato in between his time with Wasps and Wales. He spent five years in Ireland from 1996 on top of his 12 in Wales.

“I am really excited about this year because in the 2015 World Cup we struggled with depth,” he said. “We have worked on that and there is now so much more competition that players are more on edge about being selected with youngsters coming through. We are in a healthy spot. I feel very privileged to have coached Wales and had the Principality Stadium as a home ground. There is no better place to play rugby.”
